title: Snooker news: Mark Selby a victim of his own success as he struggles to meet sky high standards
text:
Mark Selby is searching for his brilliant best form (Picture: Getty Images)

Mark Selby is battling his opponents and his own lofty expectations as he looks to win his first title in over a year this week at the English Open.

The three-time world champion is going through something of a dry spell, by his own incredibly high standards, last lifting a trophy at the China Championship in September 2018.

With eight Triple Crown titles to his name, and 15 ranking titles, the 36-year-old is not used to this lack of silverware, and often a lack of a challenge for trophies, as that China Championship win was the last time he reached a final.

Things appear to be turning round for the Jester from Leicester with two ranking semi-finals out of three events this season, but Selby admits that he needs to get over this mental block by winning a tournament.

‘It’s a tough one because over the last four or five years I’ve had such good seasons,’ Selby said after his first round win at the English Open over Barry Pinches. ‘I won five tournaments one year, then anything less than that it seems like a failure which is obviously not the case because it’s tough to win any tournament nowadays.

‘Even if I was to lose in the final and it’s still not good enough because of what I’ve achieved in the game and when you’ve set your standards so high. Until I win another tournament my confidence probably won’t come back.

Selby lifting the China Open trophy in 2018 (Picture: Getty Images)

‘I’ve started off the season okay, I’m still searching for my best form, I’m playing okay in patches but it’s just not consistent. I’m playing a good game, then a poor game, then a good game, so it’s just a matter of riding the wave and hopefully it will turn around sooner or later. Keep putting the hard work in, that’s all I can do.’

The vagaries of form are such that it is very difficult to pin down why good results come and go, Selby is certainly none the wiser.

‘I don’t know,’ Selby admitted. ‘I performed so well for a period of time, at some point, the law of averages you were always going to have a little dip. Obviously this seems to be my dip.

‘You look at John Higgins. One of the greats of the game, he went through a stage where he went missing for a while. It doesn’t make him any worse of a player.

‘Form comes and goes. Form is temporary, class is permanent. I believe that. My form at the moment hasn’t been great but that it isn’t down not to putting work in. I am trying to rectify that and have a good run.’

Selby has won three of the last six World Championships and dominated the world rankings for much of that time, holding the number one spot from February 2014 until dropping down in March 2019.

A cost of his slump in form is that Selby has relinquished that position, but he is determined to reclaim it from current world champion Judd Trump.

‘It’s one of my goals [to get back to number one]. With what I have achieved in the game, you have to still keep setting goals,’ continued Selby.

‘I have always done since the start of my career. So one of my goals is to get back to world number one.

‘I wasn’t going to stay there forever. I stayed there for four years over seven seasons, to stay there as long as I was unbelievable.

‘Now I am not there, it released a bit of pressure. The pressure is on everyone else, the expectations are more on Judd. It is still at the back of my mind to get it back and something to work on.’

Selby takes on Alexander Ursenbacher or Martin O’Donnell in the English Open second round on Wednesday as he looks to claim a Home Nations title for the first time.
